track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Tulsa Geoscience Center
track.annotation: Funding is uncertain for the Tulsa Geoscience Center.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Parents as Teachers
track.annotation: Each day, parents from across the state participate in a program called, “Parents as Teachers.” The program is funded by the Oklahoma Department of Education.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Year Round School and Willner Interview
track.annotation: A decision by the Oklahoma City School Board to convert to a “continuous learning” calendar may affect the employment picture in central Oklahoma. We talk about the economic impact of the decision with Oklahoma City University economics professor, Jonathon Willner.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Muskogee Sadler Arts Academy
track.annotation: Most of the students attending Sadler Arts Academy in Muskogee come from families living below the poverty line, or with one parent incarcerated. Sadler is a magnet school where students are exposed to a variety of arts and cultures. This year, the focus is on Russian culture, so the students staged a performance of “The Nutcracker” ballet.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Reach Out and Read
track.annotation: During this Christmas season, young people appear eager to learn about other traditions that also occur this time of year.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Community Schools
track.annotation: Public educators believe a new approach to learning is closing the gap between students in low socio-economic conditions and those who are not.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Drugs and Alcohol
track.annotation: “Operation Aware” is an anti-drug and anti-alcohol program aimed at middle school students.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Ft. Gibson Classroom
track.annotation: State-of-the-art technology was at its best recently in a Ft. Gibson classroom. Students there joined five other schools from across the country for a video conference with a guest speaker in California. In this "21st Century Classroom" report, we take a look at this unique program.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Library Computer School
track.annotation: Some librarians in Muskogee wanted to do something to help their community gain access to computers and the Internet. The library now offers classes to help its patrons learn new software.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Digital Technology
track.annotation: Members of a house subcommittee believe the state can save money on textbooks by moving from traditional printed words to digital or online texts. Some public schools have already made the switch, and they tell lawmakers that the idea not only saves money, it improves student test scores.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Students and Tolerance
track.annotation: Students all across the country are taking a stand against bullying. November 9th was "mix it up at lunch day" at schools nationwide. Students were encouraged to cross social and racial boundaries by sitting next to someone new in the cafeteria at lunchtime. We visited a participating school in Broken Arrow.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Higher Education and Minorities
track.annotation: Minority enrollment is on the rise at Oklahoma's institutions of higher education. The increase is not by accident; in the last decade, recruitment of minorities has been a priority at all of Oklahoma's colleges and universities.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Kids Word
track.annotation: Thousands of Oklahoma kids can say they have "traveled around the world." The bi-annual "Kids World" is being held this week at Tulsa's Expo Square. The festival is designed to teach children tolerance and understanding about other people and cultures.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Da Vinci
track.annotation: A new after-school program in Muskogee draws its inspiration from Leonardo Da Vinci. Students study old electronics equipment while using Da Vinci's methodology to solve problems.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Higher Education
track.annotation: A live interview with Chancellor of Higher Education, Glenn Johnson talks about a host of issues now facing higher education in Oklahoma. At a time of record high enrollments the cost of a higher education keeps going up.
